Title: Linking forum posts - solarsystem-1-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted

Input.posts:
In video 1.04 the prof describes the absorption at 0,8190 and notes the rounded edge of the line. What causes this rounding? Also what causes the line to narrow to a point at its maximum absorption? Why not sharp edges and flat maximums?
Upvotes:
1
The large spectrum he analyzes is one of the earth's atmosphere when NOT looking at Mars. He points out that the little doppler 'bump' is not present compared with the previous measurement made when Mars was at quadrature. The dips are due to different electron energy levels being activated by the wavelengths of the solar spectrum on the molecules of water in the atmosphere. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_absorption http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absorption_spectroscopy

2
I agree - but it seems like the energy levels are either On or Off so must cause an On or Off absorption. Why are they rounded?

I am not certain what instrument was used, nor how the analysis of data was done for the specific experiment, but either of these factors could produce curves

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Great question and great answer! Yes, absorption lines are created when electrons in an atom or molecule change their energy states. It would seem that in a perfect world this would be a binary process: it would be an on/off process. There would be an absorption or there wouldn’t be. But it’s more complicated than that. There are many causes of line broadening, all of which combine to form the absorption line we finally observe. There is natural broadening which is a direct result of the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. A common way of stating the uncertainty principle is, “you can’t know both the position and the momentum of a particle.” An alternative but equivalent statement is, “you can’t know the both energy change and the time lapse of a quantum process.” So if an electron changes energy levels in a certain amount of time, there is going to be some uncertainty in the process: either there will be a large energy uncertainty in a short lifetime, or a small energy uncertainty in a longer lifetime. This creates a broadened line. There is also t hermal Doppler broadening . This occurs because the molecules/atoms doing the absorption of light are going to be moving and have a range of velocities. Therefore, when an electron changes energy levels, the light emitted will be red or blueshifted depending on the motion of the atom of molecules. This red/blue shift is the same as Prof Brown talked about in this lecture (1.04). There is also pressure broadening , which occurs due to collisions between atoms/molecules as the electrons moves between energy levels. I would guess that this is less common in planetary atmospheres. There is another Doppler broadening effect due to the macroscopic rotation of the body doing the absorbing/emitting. So if Mars is rotating, that would broaden its lines. Those last two probably more likely to occur in stellar spectra than in planetary spectra. Finally, there is instrumental broadening . This is due to the interaction between the light you’re observing and the instrument you’re using. Good spectral analyses usually try to account for the instrumental broadening profile. So, in summary, broadening basically occurs because of everything that happens to the light between when it is emitted and when you observe it.

Hi Barry, You are partially correct. However, for radiative transfer, the vertical scale (height) is irrelevant. It is the optical depth distribution that matters. Neglecting scattering, optical depth is essentially related to how absorbing the particular gas is at a given wavelength. In particular, for weakly absorbing (transparent) wavelengths, radiation will be 'seen' (from space) to emerge from the low levels of the atmosphere and surface, whereas for highly absorbing wavelengths, energy will be seen to emanate from further up in the atmosphere. The more optically thick the column becomes, radiation will be originating from 'layers' more and more close to your sensor. Similarly, if you were standing on Mars looking upwards at the sky, you'd see radiation coming from right above you (at absorbing wavelengths) and see almost no radiation...or just the cosmic background radiation of space...for energy that was transparent in your wavelength region of interest. Shown below is a plot of the emission spectra for Earth, Mars, and Venus (from an article by Ray Pierrehumbert at UChicago). This shows the observed intensity of radiation at every wavelength (Actually wavenumber, which is 1/wavelength) for the terrestrial planets. The blackbody curves shown in class are illustrated in black dashed or dotted lines. So, basically, when the 'observed' curve lies along a Planck blackbody curve corresponding to more intense energy, (for Earth and Mars) the emission is coming from lower-down, closer to the surface. But there are some dips in the graph (e.g., at 700 1/cm) where intensity is weak, and the emission is substantially below what you'd expect from a body at surface-like temperatures. Instead, the emission 'looks like' what a blackbody would give off at a much colder temperatures, somewhere high up in the atmosphere. These happen to be strongly absorbing regions (CO2 in this case). For Earth and Mars, there is a good mix of transparent and absorbing wavelengths. Mars actually has a much weaker greenhouse effect than Earth, since the air density is so low. This is qualitatively depicted with squiggly arrows on the right, which shows various heights from which you'd expect thermal energy to emerge in the Earth or Martian column. On Venus, the emission at all wavelengths is substantially below what you'd expect from its 730 K surface temperatures. Looking at Venus in the infrared, you might infer it was colder than Mars, since the column is so optically thick that radiation doesn't escape until it reaches the very topmost parts of the atmosphere. It wasn't until people looked in microwave wavelengths (or sent a probe down) that the hot surface temperatures were confirmed.

Hi Barry, You are partially correct. However, for radiative transfer, the vertical scale (height) is irrelevant. It is the optical depth distribution that matters. Neglecting scattering, optical depth is essentially related to how absorbing the particular gas is at a given wavelength. In particular, for weakly absorbing (transparent) wavelengths, radiation will be 'seen' (from space) to emerge from the low levels of the atmosphere and surface, whereas for highly absorbing wavelengths, energy will be seen to emanate from further up in the atmosphere. The more optically thick the column becomes, radiation will be originating from 'layers' more and more close to your sensor. Similarly, if you were standing on Mars looking upwards at the sky, you'd see radiation coming from right above you (at absorbing wavelengths) and see almost no radiation...or just the cosmic background radiation of space...for energy that was transparent in your wavelength region of interest. Shown below is a plot of the emission spectra for Earth, Mars, and Venus (from an article by Ray Pierrehumbert at UChicago). This shows the observed intensity of radiation at every wavelength (Actually wavenumber, which is 1/wavelength) for the terrestrial planets. The blackbody curves shown in class are illustrated in black dashed or dotted lines. So, basically, when the 'observed' curve lies along a Planck blackbody curve corresponding to more intense energy, (for Earth and Mars) the emission is coming from lower-down, closer to the surface. But there are some dips in the graph (e.g., at 700 1/cm) where intensity is weak, and the emission is substantially below what you'd expect from a body at surface-like temperatures. Instead, the emission 'looks like' what a blackbody would give off at a much colder temperatures, somewhere high up in the atmosphere. These happen to be strongly absorbing regions (CO2 in this case). For Earth and Mars, there is a good mix of transparent and absorbing wavelengths. Mars actually has a much weaker greenhouse effect than Earth, since the air density is so low. This is qualitatively depicted with squiggly arrows on the right, which shows various heights from which you'd expect thermal energy to emerge in the Earth or Martian column. On Venus, the emission at all wavelengths is substantially below what you'd expect from its 730 K surface temperatures. Looking at Venus in the infrared, you might infer it was colder than Mars, since the column is so optically thick that radiation doesn't escape until it reaches the very topmost parts of the atmosphere. It wasn't until people looked in microwave wavelengths (or sent a probe down) that the hot surface temperatures were confirmed.

Upvotes:

I found this paper from Sleep, 1994 in Journal of Geophysical Research http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/94JE00216/abstract;jsessionid=1ED362D153FDE9262DB6C53EE0E... There was indeed plate tectonics at some point in Mars history. The paper mentions that the lower gravity on Mars allowed for different (read: faster) plate tectonics than experienced here on earth. With this perspective, it makes sense to observe an almost perfect alignment of volcanoes if the 'hot spot' travels faster (or more correctly, if the crust moves faster atop the hot spot) than say, the Hawaiian hot spot. Another interesting feature from this picture is that the distances between volcanoes 1, 2 and 3 seem to be equal... Food for thoughts.

Input.threadtitle: On measuring the temperature of Mars
Input.posts:
I'm enjoying the lectures so far, a lively and informative presentation! One thing I don't understand though - the section on measuring the temperature of Mars. As the radiation from Mars travels through through the telescope, it bounces off of mirrors and passes through lenses, which I would think all have an influence on the signal. Indeed they are probably warmer than what you are trying to measure o n Mars. So isn't this a bit like trying to see something faint through a telescope that glows? How is this issue resolved? Nick
Upvotes:
2
Nick, That is an interesting question. I don't think the reflection in the telescope affect the wavelengths or the intensities. I think from the videos they are looking at a specific wavelength and its flux, perhaps its redshift. Those properties seem to pass unchanged through the telescope.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Good question! Richard is right. The reflection doesn't change the wavelength of the emission or its intensity. A bad mirror can, however, add its emission. But telescope mirrors are made to be as reflective -- and therefore not emissive -- as possible. As a test, you could get one of those hand held temperature measuring things and try to measure the temperature of your grill by looking at a reflection of it in a mirror. You'd still get the same answer!
